label: 094. Madame Baptiste to Bp Patrick Lynch -- March 2, 1860
description: Madame Baptiste writes to Bishop Patrick Lynch about plans that had fallen through for the Archbishop to visit Columbia.  Madame Baptiste expresses relief in the change of plans claiming, "I hate meeting dignitaries." She also brings up the issue of selling the copyright to the "Ursuline Manual" and writes at length about a young lady who wants to be a nun despite her mother's disapproval. March 2, 1860. 4p.

Madame Baptiste expresses relief in the change of plans claiming, "I hate meeting dignitaries." metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: JMJ Ursuline Convent. Columbia. S. C. March 2nd [1860?] My dearest Brother. I am sorry to learn through your hurried letters that you were indisposed & obliged to travel-- I hope the Archbishop will soon feel much better. It was quite a relief to me when I found you did not contemplate bringing him up to Columbia. I would of course feel complimented to in forming the acquaintance of so great a man, & one whom every one must admire yet I hate meeting dignitaries. You will be glad to learn my dearest Brother that Mrs [Gaffney?] is here, & has paid us in full-- consequently [written on side of page:] I hope Anna told you that all are quite well Francis & all-- [End Page 1] we have in Bank $1400.00 for which we feel truly grateful, since I trust we will be able to manage without calling on you, & in the mean time, you know how happy we will be to accommodate you with the use of any--. I Wrote to you in great haste to Baltimore because I wished to answer a letter I received from Messrs Kelly Hedian & Piet, saying they had just learned we had the copyright of the Ursuline Manual, & wished to dispose of it-- & as they were anxious to publish some good Prayer Book & had as yet not fixed on any-- consequently could give all this attention to it-- Please instruct me as to what would be the proper arrangements to make &c--. Today I received a letter from Murphy & c declining the purchase of the copyright of the Ursuline Manual which I had offered him hoping to pay in that way for some of our Books-- therefore I will write to the editors of the Baltimore [illegible], & accept their proposal, if we can agree[End Page 2] about the money arrangements, but I look to you for instruction--. I feel disposed to enclose Fran [Wevers?] letters to you-- she has been forced by her mother to attend the Protestant Church since she went home, & has I think her Faith tampered with, & her desire to become a Nun abused-- I went to her, offering to receive her as a boarder for the sum of $100. per annum which inducement I offered for the preservation of her Faith-- I told her so-- She thanks me for the offer, but says her father is unable to give her more & she is unwilling to take it from her younger sisters and brothers-- But wishes me to tell her who she must write to, & obtain permission to enter the Convent-- she feels that she must incur her Mothers displeasure whenever she does that, & I think wishes to do so at once-- which I am not sorry for. I will tell her to write to you-- she told me her Mother preferred you to any Catholic clergyman she had ever seen--. John & myself[End Page 3] feel most obliged to you for the fish, but must beg you not to send us any more-- it is a losing business-- we never could consume such a quantity it spoils on our hands-- we have tried to dispose of some of it, but without success-- so between the freight, the quantity-- & last tho not least your part of the trouble-- I think it just as well to get all that we want in Columbia, unless [once?] in a way. We are preparing for Sr Mary's reception on Sunday evening the 25th of March, If you can manage to be here-- which I hope you can-- I will give the Choir up in toto to the children-- & try to make it all as impressive as possible, & have it public-- letting Fr. OConnell give it out in Church & we invite the friends of the Convent [;?] Let Me Know in time please, if you can come I will await your instructions on all the contents of this letter-- We all write in grateful respects [by?] your benediction. Present to his Grace all respects etc--. Please pray for you own sister Ellen Sr Baptiste--[End Page 4]
